(weakly) Seems I’m married to a bug. She hesitates as she looks him up and down.
Yeah. A samurai bug. She smiles grimly, holding onto Beetle’s arm.
You are my quest. You always have been.
Hanzo. Keep him safe. No matter what.
I promise I will. Suddenly, Beetle YELLS in agony as the Sister appears beh him and plunges her blade deep into his back.
Beetle slumps down beside Monkey, who looks up, dazed and horrified, as the Sister stands over them. She raises her blade above Monkey’s head. Monkey looks over to Kubo.

Fly home, Kubo. Time seems to slow down. The only sound we hear is the qu THUMPING of Monkey’s weakened heartbeat. THUMP... THUMP... Kubo races towards the shamisen, reaching out his hands. THUMP... THUMP... The Sister’s sword carves through the air toward Monkey’s neck. THUMP... THUMP... Kubo grabs the shamisen, raking his bachi across the stri so violently that two of them actually snap in half, and REVERBERATING SOUND of the shamisen swallows up everythin with a shockwave of blinding white light.

DISSOLVE THROUGH to find Kubo on hands and knees, blinkin his eye as he tries to get his bearings. Around him are pieces of the Sister’s broken mask. In fro of him lies the netsuke statue. It is broken in half. Beetle’s broken bow lies next to him. Out of silence we gradually become aware of the slight bu steady PLUCKING of a string. Dull. Empty.
+ eH

Kubo kneels, cradling the shamisen with the two broken strings in his lap as a steady stream of teardrops fall f his face and repeatedly strike the one remaining string. Behind him, with the sound of each tear, shredded scraps paper surge up into a tiny blizzard. Within it a pathetic flimsy version of Little Hanzo begins to take shape. Sensing something, Kubo turns to see the figure there. A pitiful, torn version of its former self. But Hanzo Origami is not giving up. Using all of his strength, he drags himself across the floor and points hi sword again. He slowly rises and goes over to the place where Hanzo fe and sees the diminutive figure, damaged but undeterred, pointing with his sword and staring up at Kubo beseeching Finally, Kubo turns to see what he was pointing at. It’s illustration of the Helmet Impenetrable. Only from here i looks exactly like the bell in Kubo’s village. CLOSE ON his face, staring as realization dawns. Kubo packs his bag with the sword, Hanzo Origami, and the broken netsuke. He ties the straps of the breastplate ont the side and then steps over Beetle’s broken bow. He paus for a moment as he looks at it. Then he kneels down and t the bowstring from the shattered wood and wraps it around wrist alongside his mother’s bracelet. And then he picks up his shamisen, closes his eye, and st for a moment in the center of the courtyard, the only sou the FLAPPING of the frayed beetle banners as they billow the wind. Kubo plays one last note, PLUCKING the string as hard as can, snapping it completely. With a RUSTLING, the beetle banners flutter more violentl twisting and folding and breaking off their mounts. The banners envelope him, intertwining with his own robe to become a magnificent pair of wings that lift him up into air, soaring above the ruins...
The bell rings above the village ruins. It has been utter decimated, like a bomb went off. The once lively and colo place has been burned to the ground.

Kubo‘s new wings fly him across the landscape and land hi central avenue near the bell tower. Kubo struggles to his feet and stares up at the bell. Kubo steps over to the blackened wooden scaffold of the b tower. It’s quiet enough to hear his footsteps CRUNCH as walks. And then, face determined, he starts hitting the broken tower until it crashes down with the bell. Kubo reaches in the rubble and frees the helmet.

Kubo? Is that you? The voice surprises him. He turns around. From somewhere across the other side of the main street, soot-stained face peeks out from the charred ruin of a ho It is Kameyo, and she watches the unfolding scene with wi eyes. Behind Kameyo are Hosato with Mari, and other familiar fa looking at him with awestruck curiosity.

You have to leave this place. The Moon King, he is coming. The survivors see the look on his face and don’t ask questions. They hurry through the market place toward the gate out of town. Kubo waits a moment for them to leave, puts on the helmet then takes a deep breath. His hand tightens its grip on t sword hilt, and he looks up at the full moon hanging ominously in the sky. Unblinking.
GRANDFATHER! IT’S ME! KUBO! I KNOW
There’s a moment of silence as the echoes of his shout dissipate, and Kubo whirls around to confront the BLIND O MAN from his dream. Now he wears regal robes that glow in moonlight.
Hello, Grandson. It’s so good to see you at last. So to speak. He CHUCKLES. Gentle. Winsome. Utterly insincere. Kubo picks up a rock.
+ eH

GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) And I see you found the armor. Seems your mother had a reason to bring you to this dreadful place after all. Kubo throws the rock at Grandfather. Grandfather’s hand snatches the rock out of the air as it comes at him. GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) I see. His face still placid, he calmly squeezes up his fist and crushes the projectile to dust.
I know you do. That’s how this all began. You finally saw me. That was my fault. I should have listened to my parents.
Kubo, we both want the exact same thing.
You want to take my other eye. That’s what you want.
Well, yes, but do you know why I want it?
Because you’re old, and mean, and cruel. He takes a breath and smiles affably.

Oh now, that’s a little harsh. As long as you cling to that silly, useless eye, you can’t come up to live with me in the heavens. Grandfather keeps moving closer to Kubo as he speaks. GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) You’1l be stuck down here in this hell. Staring with that lonely eye at hate and heartache and suffering and death. (MORE )
GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) Where I want to take you we have none of those things. It will just be you with your family. Where you belong.
My family is gone. You killed them.
No! They brought their fates upon themselves. They disgraced me and upset the order of everything.
That’s how your story goes.
Oh, Kubo. When you’re up there with me you will be beyond stories. You will be immortal. You will be... infinite.

No, you're wrong. Not infinite. All stories have an end. Grandfather narrows his eyes. We get the sense he will on play this game so long. He’s starting to look a little pa and more... wrinkly... than before. Grandfather’s skin is slowly taking on the appearance of a milky cataract-like shell. Cracks on his face splinter across the surface lik shattered glass.
Is that right? And how does this story end? Kubo fixes his grandfather with a look filled with fire.
I kill you! Kubo raises up his sword, ready for battle.
Oh, very well. Is this your wish? To do battle with the hideous monster who ruined your life? To prove your worth like your doomed father? How mortal.

Grandfather throws open his arms and his entire body brea apart like a cocoon. We see the blur of a hideous head trailing a long serpentine body as it launches a hundred into the air. Seeming smaller than ever, Kubo stands ther looking up at this towering beast. The Moon Beast LAUGHS, shaking the very foundation of the devastated village. Kubo YELLS, and runs at the beast, sword held high. It lunges down at him, fangs bared. Kubo leaps, spinning its head and slashing at its pearly white flesh. The swor connects with a flash of sparks, like metal on metal. The beast recoils, but whether it’s out of pain or surpri is not immediately clear. Kubo is upon it again, a dazzli barrage of blows forcing the monster further back. Gaining the advantage, Kubo lunges with his sword, slicin deep into the creature's vast white eye. The beast ROARS thrashes, its enormous tail decimating a scorched buildin behind it. Furious, the beast twists around and comes at Kubo. He du through a charred doorway and somersaults out of a window the creature bulldozing the entire building behind him. Kubo jumps and weaves as the monster lashes out. Each tim evades its claws or maw, he scores a hit with his sword. The beast relentlessly pursues him through the blackened shells of ruined homes. Despite his agility and tenacity, Kubo is running out of breath. It seems he’s fighting a losing battle. Exhausted, he stumbles, and the beast’s jaws lock down ar his body. The armor buckles and cracks around him, and Ku is spat out, SMASHING through the remains of a wall. Painfully, Kubo crawls back onto his feet, bruised and bloodied. The creature snaps its tail like a whip, coiling around Kubo’s body and pulling him up in front of its terrible f The spiky tip of its tail hooks under the lip of Kubo’s helmet and flips it off his head. Giant tendrils of saliva fly out of its mouth as it hisse

You want to be human? Then share their weakness! The tail around Kubo squeezes tight, crushing him. MOON BEAST (CONT’D) Suffer their humiliation! The spiky tail tears the patch off Kubo’s face. MOON BEAST (CONT’D) Feel their pain! The beast throws Kubo contemptuously to the ground. He la in the dust beside the Sword Unbreakable. As Kubo goes for it the Moon Beast strikes him with its enormous tail, flinging him like a rag doll through the a

Kubo CRASHES through branches and bushes, cartwheeling through the undergrowth leading down to the riverside cemetery outside the village. He eventually comes to a stop, barely conscious. His bag lands nearby, its contents strewn around him. In the distance we hear the Moon Beast ROAR as it smashes through the village on its way to finish Kubo off. Kubo blinks. Slowly pulls himself off the ground. He reaches out for his sword. From beneath his robe sleev the two bracelets around his wrist are exposed. His mothe hair and Beetle’s bow string. Kubo’s fingers pause over the top of the sword hilt. And withdraw. And then, as quickly as he can, he deftly begins re-strin his shamisen, using both string and hair. The Moon Beast thunders closer through the woods. Two strings in place, Kubo stares at the empty space wher the final string should go. The Moon Beast appears, and finds Kubo kneeling on the ground, shamisen in hand.
This is the end of your story. Now take one last look with that lonely eye. One last look at this wretched Place you call home. Kubo stands up. Defiant.
I’m not leaving. He then reaches up and plucks out a hair from his own hea and stretches it across the shamisen. The Moon Beast CACKLES.
For every horrible thing down here there’s something far more beautiful. My mother saw it. So did my father. I see it, even with just one eye. The Moon Beast SNARLS, no longer finding this amusing.
Then I’1l just have to rip it out of your head again, won't I? As the Moon Beast goes to strike, Kubo plucks the first string on the shamisen, producing a single BOOMING NOTE.

head_text.subj: IF YOU MUST BLINK, DO IT NOW

text: The Moon Beast stops, surprised. All the dead paper lanterns in the river suddenly ignite again, a trail of light snaking from the river all the wa the broken lanterns scattered throughout the marketplace.
I know why you want my eye. Because without it I can’t look into the eyes of another and see their soul. Their love.
Everything you loved is gone! Everything you knew has been taken from you! When Kubo speaks, his voice is stronger than ever.

No. It’s in my memories. The most powerful kind of magic there is. Kubo plucks the second string. And now, emerging from behind trees and grave markers, co the surviving villagers. They hold glowing lanterns as th march to take their place alongside Kubo. Kubo plucks the final string, producing a NOTE that echoe endlessly, and the Moon Beast stares down with an express of shock. Yet more figures are joining the ranks of Kubo’ army, but these are glowing with the same otherworldly li that we saw surrounding the blue herons. These are the spirits of the dead. He gestures to his army.

It makes us stronger than you’1ll ever be. These are the memories of those we have loved and lost. And if we hold their stories deep in our hearts, then you will never take them away from us. Kubo stands there defiantly, looking up at the Moon Beast who has clearly heard enough. The beast rears back and strikes down at Kubo like an enormous snake. But as his fanged head lunges at Kubo’s army, it is defle by a field of blue light that has appeared around them, j like the glow that protected Mother’s boat in the prologu The Moon Beast is stunned. Shakes his head. Then he strik again. And again. Each time he is repelled by the field w keeps on growing larger and brighter.

And that really is the least of it. With that, he brings his hand down on his shamisen, STRUM all three strings at once. The blue glow explodes, and everything is swallowed up in blinding white light.
The glare slowly dissipates, and in front of Kubo now sta the sweet-faced old man from Kubo’s dream. He looks aroun confused.
Where am I? Kubo approaches him and kneels down.
Hello, Grandfather. The old man stares at Kubo. Genuinely puzzled.
Hello. What happened to your eye? Kubo stares at his grandfather, a little uncertain.
Don’t you remember? The old man shakes his head.
I’m sorry, young man. But I seem to have forgotten my story. Can you help me? It takes a moment for this to sink into the crowd, and th Kamekichi pushes forward.
I’1l tell him. No, we’ll all tell him. We’1l tell him everything he needs to know. As Kubo watches, the old woman approaches the old man, wa at first, as if testing the water.
You... are the kindest, sweetest man to ever live in this village. The old man seems surprised.
Oh... Oh really? Kameyo breaks into a grin and nods vigorously.
Yes! Other villagers around her are starting to get the idea.
(stepping forward) Every day, you walk around smiling and handing out coins to children... like me!
And old women!
(unsure) Oh... Soon, each of the villagers is shouting out details of th old man’s “story.”
You... you taught my kids to swim!
And... you give blankets to the poor!
You’re a good man.
You fed the hungry.
You always lend a helping hand!
You're a great example!
Oh. Turns out I’m pretty selfless.
That’s why we love you! Kameyo leans in close to the Old Man.
You know, we have something in common. We both adore your grandson. She gestures to Kubo.
His name is Kubo.
Kubo....I’m sorry, but I don’t remember.
Well, your grandson’s a storyteller. He’1ll tell you all the stories you’ve forgotten.
Really? She winks at Kubo.
Of course.

Under the tiniest sliver of moon, a long procession of villagers heads down the forest path leading to the river They hold glowing paper lanterns as they move along solem Their departed loved ones walk alongside, identifiable by subtle “spirit glow” emanating from them in the moonlight When they reach the river, farewells are said and lit lanterns set adrift once more.
The last of the remaining villagers file back up the path Kubo assembles his new altar. On it, he places two unlit lamps, then gets to his knees, facing them. He begins speaking quietly.
Hello, Mother. Father. I know my stories can tend to get a little, um, long. So I'll keep this brief. Kubo pauses, thinking what he wants to say.
I am very grateful. I have had the chance to meet you both. (MORE )

Hear your wisdom. Feel your kindness. Even eat a meal sitting between you. This was a happy story. (a beat) But...It could still be a whole lot happier. Kubo leans closer to the altar, losing some formality now

And I don’t know exactly what the rules are or how this works. But if there were any way to... y’know. I still need you. So I could say this has been a happy story. Or I could feel it. We could all feel it. And then we could end this story... together. A beat, and then he looks up again in growing wonder as a light spills across his face.
A long silence, and then we start to hear the first few n The Song of the Dead.
Reflected in the river. Glowing blue heron sail in front it, singing their sweet song. We TILT UP across the surface of the water to find where herons are coming from...

Floating along the river, heading out to sea, paper lamps refolding themselves and rising up out of the water, thei light swelling brighter and brighter as they transform in glowing blue heron. The newly-formed paper birds then flap their wings and ri up off the water to join the rest of their flock in the s

This wondrous sight is witnessed by three figures standin shadow at the river’s edge. The shortest of the figures l up into the moonlight. It is Kubo, his face still partial hidden in shadow, but we can see he’s wearing a huge smil And now we see why... Standing on either side of him, their hands resting gentl his shoulders are HANZO & MOTHER, young and resplendent. there is a “spirit glow” around them, we can’t quite see in this light. They seem as alive and tangible as Kubo himself. His eye sparkles in the moonlight as he looks up at the h soaring above the sea in the night Sky.
The end.
